Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Generalizable Similarity and Proximity Metrics for Data Exploration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowledge bases organize information into graphs of entities, and data exploration algorithms can leverage mathematical properties of these graphs to discover interesting and useful insights about the entities and their relationships. For example, data exploration algorithms can use the graph of Google Knowledge Base to identify people who have common interests, and can discover genes with similar behavior by analyzing the graph of the Genome Knowledge Base. Currently, data exploration tools tend to be quite sensitive to the details of how information is represented in these graphs, making the tools highly effective over some choices of representation but not so effective with others. As a result, data exploration has largely remained the province of experts and data scientists. This project seeks to overcome this dependency and enable a new generation of more general data exploration tools that ordinary users can use to explore data on their own, without an expert by their side.

More specifically, this project is creating effective similarity and proximity search algorithms that deliver the same results over various choices of representation for the underlying knowledge base. The key idea of the project is to use statistical metrics to quantify the degree of similarity between entities or patterns, in a manner that is not sensitive to the specific representation of the data. This novel theoretical framework serves as the foundation of more general data exploration algorithms, whose generality and effectiveness is being validated on large real-world knowledge bases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data exploration tools tend to be quite sensitive to the details of how information is represented, making the tools highly effective over some choices of representation but not so effective with others. As a result, data exploration has largely remained the province of experts and data scientists.  In this project, we worked to overcome this dependency and enable a new generation of more general data exploration tools that ordinary users can use to explore data on their own, without an expert by their side.

To move towards this goal, we introduced and formalized the property of representation independence for similarity/proximity search algorithms over data graphs. Representation independence guarantees that an algorithm will deliver the same high-quality answers over any representational variant with the same information content.

Not every representational shift preserves information content. We identified two common representational variations in data graphs that do preserve content, namely, relationship reorganization and entity rearrangement. In relationship reorganization, nodes used to specify a certain relationship between entities are added or removed without disturbing the relationship. In entity rearrangement, the edges used to express a relationship between entities change, without disturbing the relationship itself. We introduced a new version of similarity search algorithm PathSim that is representation independent across all representational variants that can be produced by relationship reorganization and entitiy rearrangement.

We also observed that representational variations beyond simple renaming require the existence of non-trivial data constraints. We considered the set of constraints in the form of tuple-generating dependencies written as conjunctive regular path queries, and predicted the possible structural variations allowed under those constraints. We showed that the existing nested regular expression language used to describe relationships in similarity search was insufficient to specify relationship patterns over all these structural variations of a dataset, and fixed this problem by adding an additional operation that can ignore the existence of some paths. We introduced a new version of similarity search algorithm PathSim that uses the extended language to define similarity, and proved that the new algorithm is design independent across all the structural variations induced by these tuple-generating dependencies.

This project supported the graduate studies of a member of an underrepresented group in STEM.
